subject: Re: [junit] does junit.textui.TestRunner.run return a non zero status code? ( junit & ant problem)
msgSnippet: Joi, Thanks for the tip.  Unfortunately, I m running this on an NT platform.  I should have mentioned my platform.  Sorry. Let me ask this.  Where can I get
messageBody:
Joi,
Thanks for the tip. Unfortunately, I'm running this on an NT
platform. I should have mentioned my platform. Sorry.

Let me ask this. Where can I get the apis and source for the
TestRunners? I don't see it in the downloads. Is it in the CVS? I
haven't used CVS before, but I will if I need to. Can anyone point
me to where I might get this? (Did I miss something in the
download?) I'm using JUnit 3.5.

Thanks.
Perry Tew


--- Joi Ellis <joi@...> wrote:
> On Fri, 2 Feb 2001 perry.tew@... wrote:
>
> > Hello. I'm learning junit, and I'm working through one of the
> tutorials
> > listed on junit.org titled "Incremental development with Ant and
> JUnit".
> > The problem I'm having is that when I run ant, my junit reports
> an error,
> > but ant reports an overall success. If I add a System.exit(1) to
> the end of
> > my main method in my Test program, ant reports a FAILURE. I'm
> following the
> > tutorial as it's written, but I can't seem to make ant fail when
> junit does.
> > Would someone please look at my build.xml (trimmed), junit code,
> and my
> > output and see if I'm making a mistake somewhere?
>
> I don't know if this is the problem you're having, but there is an
> open
> issue on Sun's Bug Parade about System.exit() not passing its
> parameter
> back to the platform. At all. It's been causing lots of problems
> for
> people calling 1.3's javac from makefiles.
>
>
> http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/bugParade/bugs/4388732.html
>
> Apparently this is a glibc issue most often seen on Red Hat 7.0.
>
> http://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23758
>
>
> Perhaps one of these issues is causing your Ant/Junit combination a
> similar headache.
> --
> Joi Ellis Software Engineer
> Aravox Technologies joi@..., gyles19@...
>
> No matter what we think of Linux versus FreeBSD, etc., the one
> thing I
> really like about Linux is that it has Microsoft worried. Anything
> that kicks a monopoly in the pants has got to be good for
> something.
> - Chris Johnson
>
>
